task.summary: Default task
First commit
Finally should be complete, all tests are working. I need to test phase scheduler on its own and the new plant production but so far so good
Almost done re-writing scenarios
Added a look-ahead and an embryonic supply chain that still doesn't function. Probably I need to look into shorter chains first
Added a few bug fix and a monopolist with inputs which now works. Supply chain is still a bit wacky
fixed marginal profit maximizer, a bit
A few more fixes
made some modifications, made monopolist as a test case too. Not entirely satisfactory. Supply chain still borked
switched most libraries to MAVEN repositories.
added data collection and tested CSV writing
Created a simple hill-climber using PID to set its targets but it works very poorly as the tests show
Created a new maximizer that uses marginal prices but has a variable step size given by PID. Need to work on calibration
MAde small change to the monopolist so that it would take enum to choose which class to use. This was sort of useless because it turns out that mason can't handle enums either
Added a cascade sales department control. Tested only the very basic of it
Added a variable inventory askpricing strategy for sales department that uses as target a smoothed daily production
Switched from an ArrayList phase scheduler to a random queue, less precise but slightly faster. Tested fine
added a new input out counter. fixed a few tests. Still a mess
Found a problem with sales department self-multiplicating. Now I can finally focus on getting some tests to work again
rebuild the array list phase scheduler now that i know it wasn't its fault
apparently I can make most tests of monopoly work just by giving it a bit more time and dividing FLOW PID SELLER a and b by half. Tuning,tuning,tuning,tuning.

fixed the annealing maximizer; prevented it from getting stuck at 0 when temperature was still too high and rewrote the test to make it statistical since there is somewhat of randomness involved in choosing the right direction
added a simple one link supply chain, same problems
forced PIDHillClimbe to work on marginal efficency instead
commiting work in progress for fear of losing everything. Added a few cool things including MaximizersUNIT pid which are fun. Got much better production but very weird prices still
Made all marginal maximizer methods static. Simple work that had to be done
Finalized the cascade efficiency maximizer and tested it. Also a bit more refactoring

Another big annoying useless refactoring, this time splitting the "when to maximize" decision from "how to". This led to a lot of useless work but hey, I am running out of excuses to actually do something meaningful!
Started a big campaign to reform and rebuild purchase departments, but I have to keep it at hold for just a moment longer!
Started a big campaign to reform and rebuild purchase departments, but I have to keep it at hold for just a moment longer!

Added a new ask price strategy that uses inventory targeting to avoid counting stock-outs but focuses exclusively on flows when it comes to choosing prices. Tested thoroughly, unfurtunately I had to divide P and I parameters by half to keep it from exaggerating with prices
Changing the README to be informative now that the folder is public. Also preparing for a long profiling session as I try to figure out what's making my model so slow all of a sudden
Made my project officially open source with AFL3
Moved all pricing decisions to PREPARE_TO_TRADE phase and all maximizations to THINK. As I should have had done a long time ago. The supply-chain results look almost acceptable
Added sigmoid to the UNIT pid, I need to retune it or it won't pass the tests
pushing all intellij settings to make it easy to open on another computer
added an ant build
switched to MAVEN, move a lot of stuff around and then update junit. A useless afternoon
Well, all the source was gone during the moving. It's back now
made tuning multi-threaded, for greater glory
fixed the progress bar, forced the exit when it's time
finally dealt with the sales department price predictor which was becoming more mysterious as central. Now it has been properly shown its place and reeducated for the common good
mostly just moved some stuff around

Created yet another sales predictor that just seem to work as intended. Unfortunately that meant giving somewhat more purpose to agents which is not what I inteded, but hey, we take what we get. Also P controllers solve one-link supply chains. As long as inventories don't matter, we are fine! Which is not really fine, but okay.
Changed a bit the pid pricings, started unit testing the static methods for marginal maximizer
Finished wth marginal maxizer statics
created some scenarios where demand has a delay in order to test how to deal with it through PID
Ran all the tuning. Modified slightly the simple seller
created a few main() to print out simulation runs to draw in R. So far so good
Did minor refinements to the Sales Predictor factory. Getting ready to deal with one link supply chains. Trying to figure out if it's possible to make purchases less edgy
Added the possibility of consuming inventory that is on sale and programmed + tested the way the sales department deals with it

added the two one-link supply chain mechanisms that work as a test. This way I'll know when they stop working if I mess stuff around.
Also, fixed a bug in linear predictor
Added a lookahead (cheater) bid pricer. It works like a charm, as hown in the one link supply chain. Yay to me!
added a simple fix pricing sales predictor to test the tripolist scenario and see how important predicting elasticity really is

Set the simple flow seller to be by default with no cost override. Also refactored the monopolist a bit so that I don't have to duplicate the firm building code when using the tripolist scenario. As of now competition works fairly well with Unit PID and no demand elasticity prediction
changed the monopolist scenario so that now demand and labor supply can be sloped at random. Need to look into the marginal PID having a bit of problem with labor productivity above 1

Lowered a bit the alpha in the exponential filter in the linear extrapolation so that it's not drive exclusively by the very last days; also changed the sigmoid in the unit maximizer to be exponential; hoping this time i can find decent parameters for it
Added a different stat collector. My guess is that in supply chains only one or two firms actually survive, this should help me see that. Also another round of marginal maximizers tuning
slightly made tests easier to pass (since unit PID is not very accurate). Also made ProducersStatCollector start recording after start() is called
added documents, in particular the sage notebook solutions to the supply chain problems
Removed a few useless schedulers and added the possibility of prioritizing stepppables to the remaining 2 schedulers. Also Removed the marginal PID maximizer without a unit since it is obsolete
Not much done. Created a scenario that fixes beef monopolist right quantity and the PID do the magic, but the maximization is still off

I can get the right results also by using the fixedDecrease sales predictor. This suggests that maybe there is a way of getting the right results by using a better sales predictor. I'll try build the linear regression predictor soon
built a linear regression, not that good results. Trying wih weighted least square next

Built a predictor that uses regression to find the slope to feed to a DecreaseSalesPredictor. It works fine, but the slope learned is a bit too optimistic. It'll probably be fixed by discounting early observations through some weighted lm rather than standard OLS

Built a weighted linear regression predictor, but that also underperforms. Need to think this through. Also made the "already learned sales predictor" as a test. Need to know why beef forced monopolist doesn't work as planned anymore
seems like 10 competitors were too many. Need to investigate how that matters.
Added a fixed elasticity estimator. So far it is still meh.

Created a similar price predictor with regression for purchase department. Created the food monopolist tests. They all fail, need to work on that and on the new learningBEefMonopolist tests that shouldn't fail but do (because the plots used to work!)

made most of my supply chain tests multithreaded. Tried to find out what was the problem that broke the "learning". Reverted a lot of history and then back. Not much success except noticing that rounding/not rounding is important
created a counter to keep track of how much is produced and consumed by each economic agent. That required me to reform the start(...) methods in most agents. Should be done now
worked on a different predictor. Still doesn't work but maybe i need to invert something still

Did quite a lot of work on regression learning recently. Cleared up a bit the code and found quite a few bugs. Unfortunately the results aren't satisfactory yet. I think that's because I need to use "supply-demand" gap as a weight to observations. That will require a way to know it which is what I need to code when I come back from vienna

Started counting disequilibrium from purchase departments. Turned out there were some old weird bugs and design choices that had to be overturned to get it right. Going to start counting disequilibrium among sales departments now

Started counting disequilibrium from purchase departments. Turned out there were some old weird bugs and design choices that had to be overturned to get it right. Going to start counting disequilibrium among sales departments now

wrote competitive tests (the always climbing is a bit iffy) and then finished the learning increase/decrease. Unfortunately they don't seem to work well in competitive settings (everybody is a monopolist there, which is funny but wrong). Also the supply chain tests simply take too long. I am moving back to LinearExtrapolator, but maybe I can combine the two. Priority should be given in having small regressions, and not too often!
rearranged the way markets store data. That was just a lot of pain for no gain
Created a linear extrapolator for purchases. Sucks. I don't know if it's the learning or the competition that is at fault here
a bit more data gathering. Still prettyu bad at predicting

I was supposed to work on EveryWeekMaximizer but instead worked on CascadePIDs. I could never get them to work satisfactorily before, but now I feel a lot better about them. This should fix the occasional SellerScenario and BuyerScenario test failures. They work by having the master as P and the slave as PID.
On another news, unfortunately the linear extrapolator is very bad for purchases. Might switch to a simpler "snapshot"
Reworked a little bit more the CascadePID controllers. Also worked on a continuous maximizer, but it seems to work very poorly in competition. Which is weird because I expected it to do better then.

Very much work in progress new predictor; must be the hundreth by now. What I a currently doing is running the monopolistWithInput test often enough and stopping every time I see that there is a mistake in marginal computation. Most input problems seem gone, so I'll have to work on the seller predictor soon. How this generalize to more deceptive supply chains, I have no idea
Played a bit around the new predictors. They are mediocre. I am going to focus more on the competitive tests next. Overproduction is weird and interesting

zeroing in on the competitive issues. I made workforce like any other good (to hire every day), but the noise feeds in the maximization which is annoying. I need to think on how to do maximize with this noise.
Created a marginal maximizer that fixes the problem of noise in workers breaking stuff up. It seems to work decently, which is amazing.

changed my idea of what competitive should be. The results used to decrease a lot because all firms shared a single labor supply but they were predicting through look-ahead so in a way they all were acting as a monopolist (that is, predicting their price impact whenever they hird somebody). So now I made it all more natural, hr doesn't predict any different from purchase department. This gets no-profit results rather well
pushing some docs, also removed the unit pid tests. Unit PID is old and annoying. Not supported anymore.
Some important bugfixes
fixed a few final bugs, all tests pass except the supply chains. Getting there

Moved Priorities around a bit more, lowered the P value of the Master PID, forced robust maximizer to hire a worker for at least 10 steps (in order to avoid getting stuck at the very beggining with SmoothedInventory strategies).
fixed some tests. There is something off in having food sales department predict 0 in supply chains
past week I set up some genetic algorithms for the win, but it seems like the supply chain monopolist is just unable to learn
Comitting a lot although not still done. Mostly I made maximization faster so that most delay problems don't ruin learning, but I still need to find a decent window/workers frame

1) Few modification to update the GUI looking for publication
2) Modified learning so that it really requires a certain variance in the x (but still feels weird)
3) Started on oil pump geographical problem. We'll see how this turns out

1) Few modification to update the GUI looking for publication
2) Modified learning so that it really requires a certain variance in the x (but still feels weird)
3) Started on oil pump geographical problem. We'll see how this turns out
4) Made volume show up properly in the GUI
The basics of the oil market should be done. Need to make it into JavaFX stuff
Revisited a bit the GUI for GeographicalMarket, should be almost done but needs testing. Might take a break to move to Kalman filtering
mediocre results with recursive linear regression estimating a weird ARIMA. Need to find the right parameters, maybe?
Added a few more variables for RCS, still need to run a GA on it. It seems to work most of the time (in simple environments) but when it's wrong it is wrong badly
Worked on open-loop recursive. Need tofind the right weights to use to get it right
Most promising approach so far, found a nasty weird bug in SimpleFlowPID of all places. Committing before breaking
A decent, but not perfect, return to non-open loop recursive predictor
Cleaned up a bit the regression code by creating decorators. Still not satisfied
In spite of all the work, the regression still comes short when it comes to supply chains. At least sometimes
Both the weight in the regression and the speed of pricing have large effects, need to work on this next
made supply gap return float; not much esle besides that
PurchaseWeekly turned into PurchaseDaily. Some minor modifications.
Few more modifications here and there to test variability

found a nasty little bug that was annoying me quite a lot: human resources new wages were set during think/dawn sending away new hires which was stupid. Now it happens during prepare to trade when precari are going to go away anyway.

found a nasty little bug that was annoying me quite a lot: human resources new wages were set during think/dawn sending away new hires which was stupid. Now it happens during prepare to trade when precari are going to go away anyway.
Next is to understand what happens to the decision making of AlreadyLearnedCompetitors so that 1 or 2 firms have no noise, but 3 do

found a nasty little bug that was annoying me quite a lot: human resources new wages were set during think/dawn sending away new hires which was stupid. Now it happens during prepare to trade when precari are going to go away anyway.
Next is to understand what happens to the decision making of AlreadyLearnedCompetitors so that 1 or 2 firms have no noise, but 3 do
Made the PIDs slower so that they all more or less have the same prices during competitive scenarios. Not sure about this

MESSAGE.value: pushing some docs, also removed the unit pid tests. Unit PID is old and annoying. Not supported anymore.
Some important bugfixes
fixed a few final bugs, all tests pass except the supply chains. Getting there

Moved Priorities around a bit more, lowered the P value of the Master PID, forced robust maximizer to hire a worker for at least 10 steps (in order to avoid getting stuck at the very beggining with SmoothedInventory strategies).
fixed some tests. There is something off in having food sales department predict 0 in supply chains
past week I set up some genetic algorithms for the win, but it seems like the supply chain monopolist is just unable to learn
Comitting a lot although not still done. Mostly I made maximization faster so that most delay problems don't ruin learning, but I still need to find a decent window/workers frame

1) Few modification to update the GUI looking for publication
2) Modified learning so that it really requires a certain variance in the x (but still feels weird)
3) Started on oil pump geographical problem. We'll see how this turns out

1) Few modification to update the GUI looking for publication
2) Modified learning so that it really requires a certain variance in the x (but still feels weird)
3) Started on oil pump geographical problem. We'll see how this turns out
4) Made volume show up properly in the GUI
The basics of the oil market should be done. Need to make it into JavaFX stuff
Revisited a bit the GUI for GeographicalMarket, should be almost done but needs testing. Might take a break to move to Kalman filtering
mediocre results with recursive linear regression estimating a weird ARIMA. Need to find the right parameters, maybe?
Added a few more variables for RCS, still need to run a GA on it. It seems to work most of the time (in simple environments) but when it's wrong it is wrong badly
Worked on open-loop recursive. Need tofind the right weights to use to get it right
Most promising approach so far, found a nasty weird bug in SimpleFlowPID of all places. Committing before breaking
A decent, but not perfect, return to non-open loop recursive predictor
Cleaned up a bit the regression code by creating decorators. Still not satisfied
In spite of all the work, the regression still comes short when it comes to supply chains. At least sometimes
Both the weight in the regression and the speed of pricing have large effects, need to work on this next
made supply gap return float; not much esle besides that
PurchaseWeekly turned into PurchaseDaily. Some minor modifications.
Few more modifications here and there to test variability

found a nasty little bug that was annoying me quite a lot: human resources new wages were set during think/dawn sending away new hires which was stupid. Now it happens during prepare to trade when precari are going to go away anyway.

found a nasty little bug that was annoying me quite a lot: human resources new wages were set during think/dawn sending away new hires which was stupid. Now it happens during prepare to trade when precari are going to go away anyway.
Next is to understand what happens to the decision making of AlreadyLearnedCompetitors so that 1 or 2 firms have no noise, but 3 do

Next is to understand what happens to the decision making of AlreadyLearnedCompetitors so that 1 or 2 firms have no noise, but 3 do

option.name: LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE
option.value:
found a nasty little bug that was annoying me quite a lot: human resources new wages were set during think/dawn sending away new hires which was stupid. Now it happens during prepare to trade when precari are going to go away anyway.
Next is to understand what happens to the decision making of AlreadyLearnedCompetitors so that 1 or 2 firms have no noise, but 3 do
Made the PIDs slower so that they all more or less have the same prices during competitive scenarios. Not sure about this
